description:
Thyatira batis, commonly known as the Peach Blossom moth, is a species of moth belonging to the family Thyatiridae. It is found in Europe and parts of Asia, including the United Kingdom, France, Germany, and Russia.

The Peach Blossom moth has a wingspan of approximately 35-45 millimeters. It is named for the distinctive peach-colored pattern on its forewings, which are also marked with dark patches and wavy lines. The hindwings are a pale gray or brownish color.

The larvae of the Peach Blossom moth feed on various plants, including brambles, hawthorns, and other woody shrubs. They can be found during the spring and summer months, typically from April to September.

This species is considered a common and widespread moth within its geographic range. It is attracted to light sources and can often be found resting on tree trunks or walls during the day.
